title: Reports: Snow slows travel from Philadelphia to New York City; Storm intensifies in New England
text:
Reports: Snow slows travel from Philadelphia to New York City; Storm intensifies in New England February 09, 2017, 10:14:08 AM EST Topic driven playlist 
A major winter storm will continue to impact the northeastern United States through Thursday morning. The storm will bring blizzard conditions and over a foot of snow to parts of the region. 
Heavy snow threatens to bring travel to a halt across the region with over 3,100 flights already canceled, FlightStats reports. 
‚ÄúAs the storm intensifies, winds will increase Thursday, especially near the coast, creating near-blizzard like conditions from eastern Long Island northward along coastal New England,‚Äù AccuWeather Senior Meteorologist Carl Erickson said. 
RELATED LINKS 
Many roads are snow or slush covered across Pennsylvania at this hour. 
In Sunbury, Pennsylvania, a truck slid off the road and crashed into a power pole this morning. If you have to go out, take your time and drive safely. (This truck-vs-pole accident happened in the Sunbury area this AM.) #snowstorm pic.twitter.com/GjJFUGGv4h ‚Äî PPL Electric (@PPLElectric) February 9, 2017 
Roads are snow-covered and icy around New York City and Long Island this morning. All schools around New York City are closed on Thursday. Stay safe this morning, New York City. This is a serious storm. Allow extra time on your commute. Use public transportation if possible. ‚Äî Bill de Blasio (@NYCMayor) February 9, 2017 UPDATE: 1-3" per hour snowfall rates hammering NYC this morning! Thundersnow potential @breakingweather pic.twitter.com/MjLk9Aybs7 ‚Äî Reed Timmer (@ReedTimmerAccu) February 9, 2017 
Rain continues to transition to to snow throughout parts of northern New Jersey as of 6:30 a.m. EST. State officials continue to recommend that motorists avoid travel unless absolutely necessary. Change over to snow shifting eastward from the I-95 corridor into New Jersey. Temperatures dropping. #pawx #njwx ‚Äî NWS Mount Holly (@NWS_MountHolly) February 9, 2017 Weather Update - If it is not necessary to drive please stay off the roads‚òÉÔ∏èüöò #ReadyNJ #NJSP #WinterStorm #SnowDay pic.twitter.com/kfcqkiuTLQ 
Lots of reports of winter weather across major highways across eastern Pennsylvania. Speed restrictions are in place this morning in some parts of I-78, I-80, I-380, and Route 33. What a difference a few hours make. #snow #nywx pic.twitter.com/nqLTvRT0WR ‚Äî ron murphy (@isixtyfive) February 9, 2017 Winter weather on PA 33 southbound between (Beginning Of PA 33) and I-78 West/Allentown. There is a speed restriction. ‚Äî 511PA Northeast (@511PANortheast) February 9, 2017 
The National Weather Service has issued blizzard warnings for Nassau and Suffolk counties on Long Island until 6 p.m. 
NWS State College in central Pennsylvania reported 5" of snow outside of its office. The heaviest snow has since headed east. 
Snow has begun to fall in New York City as of 4:05 a.m. EST. As the snow intensifies, roadways can quickly become slushy and snow-covered for the morning commute. 
As of 3:20 a.m., thundersnow is being reported around Harrisburg, PA, with visibility down to a half mile. Farther south and east, rain is falling from Reading to Lancaster and York, but a quick changeover to heavy snow will occur within the next hour or two.
